messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "albsavoia" <albsavoia@...> wrote:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "gabrielcooper" gabriel.cooper@ wrote:
> ...
> > TDD may have a place in every organization, but IMHO in some the
> > amount of work required to implement it is monumental and perhaps
even
> > prohibitive. If your codebase is dozens of 1000 line files of
> > function-less spaghetti code maintained by mulitple programmers
across
> > multiple teams in various geographical locations... You (and your
> > organization) have a lot of work ahead of you before you can push
TDD.
> >...
>
> Hi Gabriel.
>
> Just to be clear, I was not restricting my argument to TDD infection.
> I believe that the TDD1 gene, let's call it that, is considerably more
> rare than the T1 gene. At this point in time I'd be thrilled to see
> the majority of developers writing and running unit tests on a regular
> basis; whether they write them before, during, or after the code is
> done. At this stage of the game test-first is less important than
> having the tests in the first place - gotta walk before you run.
>
> I agree that most projects out there consist of 1,000s of classes with
> no tests. I love Michael Feathers's definition: code without tests ==
> legacy code. This definition makes 95%+ of Java code legacy code.
> "Legacy code, is not just COBOL anymore" :-).
>
> Seriously, I can, and do, sympathize that sometimes the task looks
> "monumental and even prohibitive". But only if you think that you have
> to go from zero tests to 1,000s of tests right away. I don't know why
> many people think in terms of all-or-nothing when it comes to testing.
> You have to start somewhere, and something is better than nothing.
> 10,000 Java classes and 1 JUnit test is better than 10,000 Java
> classes and 0 JUnit tests. 2 tests are better than 1, and so
> forth. And look at the bright side, at least those 2 tests will run
> quickly.
>
> If you are stuck in a project like the one you describe, it's probably
> counter-motivating to even look at metrics like
> numberOfTests/numberOfClasses, or code coverage: "Hey, we achieved 5%
> code coverage. Where's the Champagne?". Instead focus on the absolute
> number of tests (a simple, positive, monotonically growing test
metric).
>
> While the "monumental pile of untested spaghetti code" does not help,
> I believe a lot of people just use that as an excuse to not get
> started. I have seen developers rejecting regular unit testing even in
> greenfield projects, so there is something more fundamental at play.
>
> Alberto
>
> http://www.junitfactory.com
> Generate JUnit tests. Free.
> Send us Java. Get back JUnit.
>
Alberto,
It does seem that unit testing is still in the 'early adopter' stage.
Developers and managers that I talk to and work with understand the
benefits to unit testing, metrics, coverage, CI, ... but do not adopt
them consistently on their projects.

I do believe that unit testing is very much a market-driven event and I
say that because of all the opinions I have heard. Most of the people I
have talked to completely agree with the benefits of unit testing and
TDD *in theory*, but do not implement a solution because of pressure
from investors, customers or other market factors. After all, isn't all
software buggy?

There are enough studies to show people the value of a good unit testing
program (TDD or not). There are also studies that show high risk may
result in high reward, which unit testing can possibly hinder.

I may be reaching here, but the question in my mind revolves around the
'event' that will change people's mind. The plublicized class action
lawsuit against a software company because of a major defect (security,
logic, whatever) will open the floodgates especially since membership in
the ABA Law Group has experienced exponential growth. Lawyers have to
do something, right :)

You started an interesting thread, and I look forward to the other
responses.

Joe
